‚öôÔ∏è In Spanish, **past participles** can function as adjectives and are used with **ESTAR** to describe a **state resulting from an action**.

üîπ **Formation of the past participle:**
- **-AR** verbs ‚Üí **-ado**: *cansar ‚Üí cansado*
- **-ER/-IR** verbs ‚Üí **-ido**: *aburrir ‚Üí aburrido*, *perder ‚Üí perdido*

üîπ **Common irregular participles:**
- **abrir** ‚Üí **abierto** (open)
- **escribir** ‚Üí **escrito** (written)
- **hacer** ‚Üí **hecho** (done/made)
- **decir** ‚Üí **dicho** (said)
- **poner** ‚Üí **puesto** (put/placed)
- **ver** ‚Üí **visto** (seen)
- **volver** ‚Üí **vuelto** (returned)
- **romper** ‚Üí **roto** (broken)
- **morir** ‚Üí **muerto** (dead)
- **cubrir** ‚Üí **cubierto** (covered)

üîπ **With ESTAR:**
The participle agrees in **gender** and **number** with the subject.

‚û°Ô∏è *Estoy cansado.* (I'm tired - masculine)

üîπ **Common examples:**

- *Estoy ocupado/ocupada.* (I'm busy)
- *Estoy aburrido/aburrida.* (I'm bored)
- *Estoy enamorado/enamorada.* (I'm in love)
- *Estoy enfadado/enfadada.* (I'm angry)
- *Estoy sorprendido/sorprendida.* (I'm surprised)

- *La puerta est√° cerrada.* (The door is closed)

üí° **Difference ESTAR vs SER:**
- **ESTAR + participle** = state resulting from an action

‚ö†Ô∏è **Attention to agreement:**
